articles.description: Thursday's court ruling puts to rest the most intense election battle the West African country has seen in decades.
articles.title: How a certificate scandal almost upset Tinubu’s presidential win in Nigeria

articles.description: Mike Johnson was elected as House speaker after three other candidates were unable to secure enough votes.
articles.title: Who is Mike Johnson, the new US Republican House speaker?

articles.description: More Israeli raids in the occupied West Bank have led to the arrests of dozens of Palestinians.
articles.title: Over 10,000 Palestinian prisoners held in Israeli jails

articles.description: Cleanup efforts under way after category 5 story hit Mexico's Pacific coast and tore through Guerrero state.
articles.title: At least 27 killed after Hurricane Otis slams into Mexico’s Acapulco

articles.description: Competing allegations over the source of the explosion at the al-Ahli Arab Hospital shows exactly why the ICC must act.
articles.title: The ICC should urgently investigate what happened at al-Ahli Arab Hospital

articles.description: From a devastated village to the start of a pre-dawn assault, an inside look at life on four front lines over four days.
articles.title: Dispatches from Ukraine’s front lines: An underground town

articles.description: Wael Dahdouh's wife, children, grandson, nephew, niece and other relatives are among those killed in air strike.
articles.title: ‘All gone’: Al Jazeera Gaza reporter’s family grieves slain relatives

articles.description: An art activity for the hundreds of displaced children taking refuge from Israel's bombs at al-Shifa Hospital.
articles.title: Finding small moments of joy for Palestinian children at al-Shifa Hospital

articles.description: First-of-its-kind waste map shows methane emissions at landfills around the world in new fight against climate change.
articles.title: Mapping methane: Satellites seek out gas-spewing waste sites

articles.description: A funeral was held for family members of Al Jazeera correspondent Wael Dahdouh after Israeli bombardment killed them.
articles.title: Funeral for family of Al Jazeera correspondent

articles.description: Holders England slumped to an eight-wicket loss against Sri Lanka, their fourth of the tournament.
articles.title: Sri Lanka beat defending champions England in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023

articles.description: US law enforcement is trying to locate suspect Robert Card after shootings in two locations of Lewiston, Maine.
articles.title: Lewiston, Maine shooting: What we know so far

articles.description: Nigeria's highest court dismisses the opposition's claims of fraud and electoral law violations.
articles.title: Nigeria’s Supreme Court affirms Tinubu’s presidential victory

articles.description:
United Nations agencies and officials on Saturday reiterated calls for a humanitarian ceasefire in Gaza after another night of heavy bombing left hospitals and healthcare facilities without electricity and civilians across the enclave virtually “cut off from the outside world”.

Read the full story, “Gaza Crisis: UN ramps up calls for humanitarian truce as Israeli bombardments cut communications, cripple healthcare”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza Crisis: UN ramps up calls for humanitarian truce as Israeli bombardments cut communications, cripple healthcare

articles.description:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct 27 (IPS) - In response to lawsuits brought by LGBTQI+ activists, the Mauritius Supreme Court has issued two landmark judgments striking down the criminalisation of consensual sex between adult men as unconstitutional. Its reasoning turned upside down the argument used by anti-rights forces to attack LGBTQI+ activists in many African countries: it acknowledged that criminalisation is the foreign import rather than gay sex, and a relic of colonialism it’s high time to shake off.

Read the full story, “Mauritius Begins to Correct a Historic Wrong Towards LGBTQI+ People”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Mauritius Begins to Correct a Historic Wrong Towards LGBTQI+ People

articles.description:
PORTLAND, USA, Oct 27 (IPS) - Among the various troubling human addictions the one having the most worrisome consequences for humanity and planet Earth is population growth.

Read the full story, “The Worst Addiction: Population Growth”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Worst Addiction: Population Growth

articles.description:
The United Nations General Assembly on Friday adopted a major resolution on the Gaza crisis, calling for an “immediate, durable and sustained humanitarian truce leading to a cessation of hostilities.”

Read the full story, “Gaza crisis: General Assembly adopts resolution calling for ‘humanitarian truce’, civilian protection”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza crisis: General Assembly adopts resolution calling for ‘humanitarian truce’, civilian protection

articles.description:
Humanitarian operations continue to deliver life-saving assistance in Ukraine, amid ongoing attacks across the country, the UN said on Friday.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Ukraine aid convoy, attacks in South Sudan, radioactive discharge update”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Ukraine aid convoy, attacks in South Sudan, radioactive discharge update

articles.description:
As the UN’s 193 Member States meet on how to address the ongoing Israel-Palestine crisis, we took a look at how the current rarely convened General Assembly emergency special session came about, what it means and why it matters.

Read the full story, “Explainer: What is a UN General Assembly emergency special session and why it matters”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Explainer: What is a UN General Assembly emergency special session and why it matters

articles.description:
As much needed aid starts to trickle into besieged Gaza, a war over facts is ratcheting up as conflicting narratives about the situation on the ground are being fuelled by social media.

Read the full story, “Explainer: Fighting for facts amid crisis in Israel and Gaza”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Explainer: Fighting for facts amid crisis in Israel and Gaza

articles.description:
With the humanitarian system in Gaza on the verge of "total collapse", UN Secretary-General António Guterres on Friday again appealed for greater aid access to the besieged enclave, where “misery is growing by the minute.”

Read the full story, “‘History is judging us all,’ Guterres says in fresh appeal for Gaza aid access”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: ‘History is judging us all,’ Guterres says in fresh appeal for Gaza aid access

articles.description:
The world cannot forget about Syria, the Head of the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on the country has said, while also highlighting how the war there is connected to the conflict raging in the Middle East.

Read the full story, “Syrian war at ‘worst point’ in four years, says Commission of Inquiry head”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Syrian war at ‘worst point’ in four years, says Commission of Inquiry head

articles.description:
Pakistan’s plan to deport “undocumented” foreign nationals will disproportionately affect more than 1.4 million Afghans in the country, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Friday, expressing alarm.

Read the full story, “Pakistan urged to halt Afghan deportations to avoid ‘human rights catastrophe’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Pakistan urged to halt Afghan deportations to avoid ‘human rights catastrophe’

articles.description:
The UN’s top human rights official issued a new appeal on Friday for an end to the Israel-Palestine crisis and the release of all hostages, amid rising civilian deaths and reports that children's names have been written on their arms so that they can be identified in case they die in the rubble.

Read the full story, “Gaza: Testimonies highlight grim plight of civilians expecting to die”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza: Testimonies highlight grim plight of civilians expecting to die

articles.description:
LIMA, Oct 26 (IPS) - The lack of water is so severe in Peru's highlands that farming families are forced to sell their livestock because they cannot feed them. "There is no grass or fodder to feed them," says Fermina Quispe, a Quechua farmer from a rural community located at 4,200 meters above sea level.

Read the full story, “Community Solutions Combat Water Shortages in Peru's Highlands”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Community Solutions Combat Water Shortages in Peru's Highlands

articles.description:
SAINT LUCIA, Oct 26 (IPS) - A new report by the University lists six areas of grave concern and states that in the absence of behavior and priority change, the world could face catastrophe in areas like groundwater depletion and species extinction.Melting mountain glaciers. Unbearable heat. An uninsurable future. Space debris. Groundwater depletion. Accelerating extinctions. The United Nations University Institute for Environment and Human Security said this week that these six environmental "tipping points" can have "irreversible, catastrophic impacts for people and the planet."

Read the full story, “Human Action Pushing the World Closer to Environmental Tipping Points, UN University Warns”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Human Action Pushing the World Closer to Environmental Tipping Points, UN University Warns
Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan
Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: The month-long Vatican meeting on the future of the Roman Catholic Church ended without clear positions on issues such as women deacons and LGBT inclusion. The meeting, called a Synod of Bishops, allowed women and lay people to vote on Church affairs for the first time. However, the final report did not take a stand on LGBT issues despite discussions beforehand. The report mentioned the need to hear and accompany marginalized individuals but did not call for greater inclusion. LGBT advocates expressed disappointment with the report. The pope will close the gathering with a Mass on Sunday.
articles.title: Vatican synod ends without clear stances on women, LGBT community

articles.description: The extensive tunnel network built by the Hamas militant group in the Gaza Strip poses a significant threat to Israeli troops and the Palestinian population. Clearing and collapsing these tunnels is crucial for dismantling Hamas, but it is a challenging task that strips the Israeli military of its technological advantages. The tunnels provide Hamas with hiding places and the ability to choose the time and location of engagement. Israeli airstrikes have targeted these tunnels, but combating underground warfare is difficult due to the abundance of ambush opportunities.
articles.title: Hamas militants holed up in 'Metro' web of tunnels pose challenge

articles.description: The ongoing conflict in Gaza has not only resulted in the loss of lives but has also disrupted the funeral rites of Palestinians, depriving them of dignity and closure. The high number of casualties has overwhelmed hospitals and morgues, making it difficult to perform traditional funeral rituals. Many bodies are unrecognizable due to decomposition or the absence of surviving family members. In an attempt to increase the chances of identification, families are resorting to wearing identification bracelets and writing names on their children's bodies.
articles.title: Mass graves & a city robbed of funeral rites

articles.description: On Saturday, the European Union and Japan reached an agreement to promote cross-border data flows, aimed at enhancing online trade between businesses and combating digital protectionism, as reported by the European Union. This pact was signed during the G7 trade ministers' meeting in Osaka and is designed to streamline online business operations, making them more convenient, cost-effective, and efficient, according to a statement from the European Commission.
articles.title: European Union, Japan strike data flows deal

articles.description: US Republican presidential candidates expressed their unwavering support for Israel and vowed to wipe out Palestinian Hamas militants during a gathering of major Jewish donors in Las Vegas. The event, organized by the Republican Jewish Coalition, comes at a time when Israel is preparing for a ground invasion of Gaza following an attack by Hamas. The candidates, including frontrunner Donald Trump, emphasized their commitment to Israel and criticized any isolationist tendencies within the Republican Party.
articles.title: US Republican presidential candidates tout Israel support in speeches to Jewish donors

articles.description: US and Chinese officials have reached an agreement in principle for a meeting between Presidents Joe Biden and Xi Jinping next month. The details and arrangements for the meeting are still being worked out, but it is likely to take place during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in San Francisco. The breakthrough follows Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi's visit to Washington, where he met with Secretary of State Antony Blinken and National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan.
articles.title: US, China agree in principle on Biden-Xi meeting in Nov

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has announced that the military has entered a "second stage" in the war against Hamas by sending ground forces into Gaza. He stated that attacks will increase ahead of a broader ground invasion and that the mission is to destroy Hamas' military and governmental capabilities and bring back the hostages. The bombardment has severely disrupted communications and paralyzed the health network in Gaza. Hamas has expressed readiness for an immediate prisoner swap with Israel.
articles.title: Israel expands ground operations; Gaza war enters 'second stage'

articles.description: A mariner who went missing off the Washington coast has been found alive in a life raft, but his companion is still missing. The two mariners set off on October 12 from Westport, Washington, but failed to return as scheduled. The Coast Guard conducted a search operation but suspended it due to a lack of leads. A Good Samaritan vessel discovered the life raft with one of the mariners inside, who managed to survive by catching and consuming a salmon.
articles.title: Fisherman missing for two weeks found alive off Washington coast

articles.description: The death toll from Hurricane Otis in Mexico has been raised to 39, with the cause of death being suffocation by submersion. The number of missing has also increased to 10. The recovery effort has been slow, with aid taking several days to arrive. Gasoline and food shortages are also being reported, with some people resorting to looting to obtain supplies. The destruction caused by the Category 5 storm has left many areas without electricity and access to basic necessities like water.
articles.title: Mexico security authorities raise Hurricane Otis death toll to 39

articles.description: Middle East News: CAIRO: Egypt's military spokesman on Sunday said an unspecified number of border guards sustained "minor injuries" from "fragments of a shell accident.
articles.title: Egypt army reports 'minor injuries' in accidental Israeli shelling

articles.description: An Army reservist who killed 18 people at a Maine bowling alley and bar purchased his weapons legally, according to authorities. The shooter, identified as Robert Card, died of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound. He had a history of mental illness, including hearing voices and expressing a desire to harm others. Card had not been involuntarily committed to a mental health facility, and a simple evaluation or voluntary commitment would not have prohibited him from owning a gun.
articles.title: Maine mass killing suspect had mental health issues, purchased guns legally, authorities say

articles.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi had a phone call to discuss the ongoing Israeli military operations in the Gaza Strip. They expressed concern about the impact on civilians and the region's security. El-Sisi confirmed Egypt's efforts to coordinate international actions towards a ceasefire and warned against a ground offensive. Both leaders emphasized their commitment to strengthening bilateral relations and cooperation between Egypt and India.
articles.title: PM Modi, Egyptian President discuss Israel-Hamas conflict

articles.description: A 75-year-old mother in Italy has taken legal action against her two sons in their 40s who refused to leave the family home. The sons, despite having jobs, had been living with their mother for an extended period and not contributing to the household. The mother sought help from the judicial system and a judge issued an eviction order against the sons. This case highlights the societal issue in Italy of adults, particularly those aged 18 to 34, continuing to live with their parents.
articles.title: Italian mother takes her two sons in their 40s to court, gets them evicted

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced that Israeli forces have entered the second phase of the war in Gaza, as they continue their ground operations against Hamas militants. The Gaza Strip is currently facing a humanitarian crisis, with limited communication with the outside world and a shortage of basic necessities. Netanyahu stated that the goal of the war is to destroy Hamas' capabilities and bring home the hostages held by the group.
articles.title: Israel launches Gaza war's second phase with ground operation, Netanyahu says

articles.description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's differing views on wealth are reportedly causing tension in their relationship. While Harry prioritizes charity work and family life, Meghan is focused on developing her personal brand for financial gains, potentially through sponsored posts on social media. Speculations about their financial priorities come amid reports of strain in their relationship, with experts advising them to remain a united front for the sake of their joint professional and financial endeavors.
articles.title: Money matters creating wedge between Harry, Meghan

articles.description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Eli Cohen, has ordered the return of diplomatic representatives from Turkey to reassess the country's relations with Turkey. This decision comes after Turkish leaders condemned Israel's military campaign against Hamas. Israeli ambassadors stationed in Turkey have been instructed to return to Israel. Turkey's President, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, referred to Hamas as 'mujahideen' defending their lands and cancelled his visit to Israel. Turkey's Foreign Minister, Hakan Fidan, accused Israel of committing "a crime against humanity" in its war in Gaza.
articles.title: Israel to reassess diplomatic relations with Turkey, says Foreign Minister Cohen

articles.description: Over 20,000 people marched through Johannesburg in support of LGBTQ+ communities in Africa who face criminalization and cannot openly express their identities. The parade was led by a Ugandan man who had fled his country after being arrested for being gay. The march aimed to raise awareness for LGBT rights in Africa, particularly in Uganda, where the death penalty for homosexuality was introduced in May. South Africa, in contrast, legalized same-sex marriage in 2006 and is the only African country to have done so.
articles.title: Johannesburg Pride marches for LGBTQ+ Ugandans after anti-gay law passed

articles.description: College campuses in the United States are experiencing a surge in activism surrounding the Israel-Palestine conflict. This activism is characterized by dueling protests and debates, with both pro-Palestinian and Jewish students facing harassment and online attacks. The divisive nature of the conflict, combined with the influence of social media, has led to a lack of consensus among students. This activism has also had broader implications, with some colleges facing accusations of antisemitism and losing donor support.
articles.title: Tension rise in US universities amid Israel-Hamas war

articles.description: Serbian police have dispatched hundreds of officers to a border area with Hungary after a shooting between migrants resulted in three deaths and one injury. The incident occurred near the Serbia-Hungary border, where reports of violence and gun battles have become common. Thousands of migrants have been camping in the area, attempting to cross into EU member nation Hungary with the help of people smugglers. Police actions are aimed at curbing irregular migration and increasing security in the region. Several have been detained, including individuals suspected of smuggling migrants.
articles.title: Hundreds of Serbian police deploy in border zone with Hungary after deadly shooting among migrants

articles.description: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres expressed surprise at Israel's escalation of bombardments in Gaza and called for an immediate humanitarian ceasefire. Guterres stated that instead of a pause, there has been an unprecedented escalation that undermines humanitarian objectives. The escalation follows Israel's reprisal for an attack by Hamas, resulting in a humanitarian catastrophe for Gaza's 2.3 million people. The communication blackout in Gaza is impeding aid efforts, including ambulances and evacuations.
articles.title: UN chief surprised by escalation of Israel's bombardment, calls for humanitarian ceasefire

articles.description: The WHO and Unicef have expressed concern over the safety of their staff and humanitarian partners in Gaza. WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus called for protection of civilians and full humanitarian access, while Unicef executive director Catherine Russell highlighted the safety concerns for children in Gaza. United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned of a potential collapse of the humanitarian system in Gaza, affecting over 2 million civilians. Israel has expanded its military campaign against Hamas, leading to increased tensions and a communication blackout in the region.
articles.title: We have lost touch with our staff, health workers in Gaza: WHO Chief

articles.description: Law enforcement in Maine continues its search for Robert R. Card, the suspected shooter responsible for the mass shootings in Lewiston that killed 18 people and injured 13. The search, which included executing search warrants in the neighboring town of Bowdoin, has so far been unsuccessful in locating Card. The town of Lewiston and surrounding communities have been on lockdown as authorities conduct their search. Card, a US Army reservist, had previously been committed to a mental health facility.
articles.title: Maine manhunt for Lewiston mass shooter extends to another night

articles.description: The names of five people found shot to death in a North Carolina home have been released by the sheriff's office. The victims were found dead from gunshot wounds and their names were announced by the Sampson County sheriff's office. The authorities are investigating the incident and have identified some people of interest. It is unclear whether the case is being treated as a mass killing. This incident comes just hours after another shooting in Maine, making it the 36th mass killing in the US this year.
articles.title: Sheriff names 5 people fatally shot in southeast North Carolina home

articles.description: The onePulse Foundation has announced that it is dropping its plans to build a museum to honor the victims of the 2016 massacre at a gay nightclub in Florida. The foundation cited financial concerns, including soaring construction costs and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the city of Orlando is still moving forward with constructing a memorial for the victims. The efforts to build a memorial and museum have been slow, with the nightclub's owners only recently agreeing to sell the property.
articles.title: Museum plan for Florida nightclub massacre victims dropped as Orlando moves forward with memorial

articles.description: Italian authorities have captured footage of the leaders of Italy's three most powerful organized crime groups - the Ndrangheta, Camorra, and Cosa Nostra - sharing a meal, raising concerns of a potential alliance. Prosecutors believe that these once-rival criminal organizations have set aside their differences to form a grand alliance, exploiting business opportunities in Italy's prosperous north. The mafia groups have shifted their focus to white-collar crime and legitimate investments, funneling drug trafficking profits into various sectors.
articles.title: Super Mafia: Rising concerns as Italy's top three gang godfathers seen sharing meal

articles.description: President Joe Biden met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi in a conversation seen as a precursor to a potential meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping next month. The meeting aimed to explore the possibility of stabilizing the tense relationship between the two countries amidst conflicts in Ukraine and Israel. Biden emphasized the need for responsible competition management and cooperation in addressing global challenges. The meeting was viewed positively, and Biden expects to meet with Xi again.
articles.title: Biden talks with Chinese foreign minister as he prepares for potential meeting with Xi

articles.description: Hamas has stated that it is prepared for an invasion of the Gaza Strip by Israel after air strikes have cut off communications in the area. Israel has announced that it is extending its ground operation in response. The military has significantly increased its strikes, leading to intense bombardment in northern Gaza. Hamas has responded with rocket fire. All internet connections and communications in Gaza have been cut, according to Hamas, who accused Israel of doing so to enable "massacres".
articles.title: Hamas says 'ready' for Israel invasion of Gaza

articles.description: Internet and phone services in Gaza have collapsed due to intensified Israeli bombardment, leaving the 2.3 million people in the strip cut off from the outside world and each other. The Israeli military's announcement of "expanding" ground operations signifies a potential all-out invasion of Gaza. This has led to a blackout in internet and communication services, exacerbating the already dire situation for Palestinians, who are huddled in homes and shelters with dwindling supplies of food and water.
articles.title: Israeli air and ground strikes intensify in Gaza; internet collapse cuts territory off from outside

articles.description: Supermodel Bella Hadid, who is of Palestinian descent, has spoken out about the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict, expressing her support for the Palestinian cause and condemning attacks on civilians. Hadid also revealed that she has been receiving death threats daily since her personal phone number was leaked. She emphasized the need for leaders to uphold the laws of war and called for pressure to be placed on them to address the urgent needs of the people of Gaza.
articles.title: 'Generational trauma of my Palestinian blood': Bella Hadid's plea for peace in Middle East

articles.description: House Republicans, led by Rep. Anthony D'Esposito, have introduced a resolution to force a vote on the removal of Rep. George Santos from Congress. Santos is facing numerous charges related to fraud and financial offenses. The resolution highlights Santos' history of promoting false information about himself and his campaign. A vote on the resolution is expected next week. Santos has admitted to inaccuracies in his personal history but has resisted calls to resign.
articles.title: House Republicans seek vote to remove George Santos over falsehoods

articles.description: A new "Siberian Battalion" has been formed by Russian nationals who have defected from Putin's army to fight alongside Ukrainian forces in the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine. The battalion includes prominent members such as Alexei Makarov and Ildar Dadin. The exact location and impact of the battalion remain undisclosed, but their presence could complicate matters for Putin's forces, who have already suffered significant losses in the conflict.
articles.title: Siberian battalion: The new Ukraine unit formed of entirely of Russians

articles.description: House Speaker Mike Johnson expressed concerns about President Biden's cognitive decline after their meeting. Johnson emphasized that this observation was not a personal insult to the President and mentioned the differences between Biden's past performances and recent speeches. The meeting revolved around Biden's request for aid to Ukraine, Israel, and other projects. Johnson confirmed that his caucus did not approve of packaging foreign aid together and advocated for separating these issues.
articles.title: 'Everyone ages differently': Newly-elected Speaker Mike Johnson on Biden's cognitive decline

articles.description: Hamas has conditioned the release of hostages in Gaza to a ceasefire in Israel's bombardment of the Palestinian enclave, which was launched after a deadly attack on southern Israel. Israel says it is preparing a ground invasion, but has been urged by the US and Arab countries to delay in order to avoid civilian casualties. Two US fighter jets struck weapons and ammunition facilities in Syria in retaliation for attacks on US forces by Iranian-backed militias.
articles.title: Release of hostages needs ceasefire, Hamas official says

articles.description: Europe News: Russian forces heavily shelled the centre of the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson on Friday, injuring a number of people and damaging at least 10 bu.
articles.title: Russians shell Ukraine's Kherson, damage and casualties reported

articles.description: US third-quarter earnings estimates for S&P 500 companies are more positive than previously expected, with a projected increase of 4.3% compared to the same period last year, according to LSEG data. This estimate has increased from the previous forecast of a 2.6% gain. The results are based on reports from half of the S&P 500 companies and estimates for the rest. Despite concerns over rising US Treasury yields, investors are closely watching third-quarter earnings following a decline in the second quarter.
articles.title: Third-quarter US earnings now seen growing 4.3% year-on-year -LSEG data

articles.description: An independent commission in Spain has estimated that over 200,000 minors have been sexually abused by the Roman Catholic clergy since 1940. The report, which surveyed over 8,000 people, found that 0.6% of Spain's adult population said they had suffered sexual abuse by members of the clergy as children. Including abuse by lay members, the percentage rises to 1.13%. The commission also interviewed 487 victims who highlighted the lasting emotional impact of the abuse. The report criticizes the Catholic Church's response, calling for the creation of a state fund to compensate victims.
articles.title: Spanish clergy sexually abused over 2,00,000 children, probe estimates

articles.description: An alliance of ethnic rebel groups in Myanmar has launched a coordinated offensive to seize military targets in areas near the Chinese border. The Arakan Army, Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army, and the Ta'ang National Liberation Army, known as the Three Brotherhood Alliance, have initiated "Operation 1027" in Myanmar's Shan state. The groups aim to safeguard civilians, assert their right to self-defense, and respond to ongoing attacks by the military government.
articles.title: Alliance of 3 ethnic rebel groups carries out coordinated attacks in northeastern Myanmar

articles.description: Pakistan's former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, faced criticism in the Senate for allegedly making sexist remarks at a rally. Sharif attacked women from the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf party for dancing at their rallies, which led to opposition and calls for him to be taught how to "respect women." This incident echoed a similar incident involving former chief of Muttahida Qaumi Movement, Altaf Hussain. Sharif's remarks were seen as sexist and misogynistic, with critics highlighting his belief that only his daughter, Maryam, should be involved in politics.
articles.title: Pakistan's former PM Nawaz Sharif under fire for using sexist remarks against PTI women supporters

articles.description: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan, currently in jail, has expressed concerns about his safety and alleged that there could be an attempt on his life through slow poisoning. Khan also criticized the caretaker government and accused them of granting reliefs to his political rival, Nawaz Sharif. He claimed that the cases against him are politically motivated and aimed at keeping him in jail. Khan urged the people to fight for their rights and the freedom of the country. He also directed his lawyers and party officials to prepare for the upcoming elections.
articles.title: 'They will make another attempt on my life...through slow poisoning': Imran Khan's message from jail

articles.description: US fighter jets conducted airstrikes on two locations in eastern Syria connected to Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps in response to recent attacks on US bases and personnel in the region. The strikes aim to deter future aggression while avoiding further escalation. The targeted sites were chosen because they store munitions used in the attacks against the US. Syrian opposition activists confirmed the strikes, and casualties are yet to be determined. Iran-backed groups have retaliated with rocket attacks on a US base in Syria and an attempted drone attack on an airbase in Iraq.
articles.title: US fighter jets strike Iran-linked sites in Syria in retaliation for attacks on US troops

articles.description: US President Joe Biden said on Wednesday he has "no confidence in the number that Palestinians are using" for the death toll in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip, where the health ministry says at least 7,028 people have been killed in Israeli attacks. Biden was asked at a White House press conference whether the death count, which the ministry says includes some 2,913 children, meant Israel was ignoring US appeals to reduce civilian deaths in its bombardment of the coastal enclave.
articles.title: Biden says has 'no trust' in Hamas' Gaza death count as 'toll tops 7,000'

articles.description: Israel has announced that it will provide compensation for ships that are damaged due to the war in Gaza. The government is also taking steps to minimize risks for vessels using the country's ports. Israel relies on its seaports for trade and basic needs, and compensation will be awarded for "war damage" caused to Israeli or foreign vessels. Additional war risk insurance premiums have increased for ships calling at Israeli ports, and some vessels have diverted to the north.
articles.title: Israel to pay compensation for ships damaged in Gaza war

articles.author: Surendra Singh
articles.description: Russian atomic energy corporation Rosatom has set a new record by installing a research reactor pressure vessel in Bolivia, making it the world's highest nuclear facility. The project, built on behalf of the Bolivian Agency for Nuclear Energy, will allow Bolivia to conduct scientific research and develop various economic sectors. The reactor will also produce radioisotopes and serve as a training tool. The project also includes a cyclotron complex and a laboratory, with completion expected in 2025.
articles.title: Russia nuclear agency Rosatom sets up world’s highest nuclear facility in Bolivia

articles.description: EU leaders have called for pauses in Israeli bombing and Hamas rocket attacks in order to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza. The leaders expressed grave concern for the deteriorating humanitarian situation and called for continued, safe, and unhindered access to reach those in need. While EU leaders have condemned Hamas' attack, they have struggled to present a unified message, with some emphasizing Israel's right to self-defense and others expressing concern for Palestinian civilians.
articles.title: EU leaders urge pauses in Gaza bombing to get aid in

articles.description: Tasneem Ismael Ahel, a 19-year-old college student in Gaza City, has become a voice in the midst of war, using WhatsApp voice notes to share the challenges faced by Palestinians in the conflict-ridden region. Her audio messages provide insight into the daily struggles of living under siege, including the fear of bombings and the scarcity of essential supplies. Despite the hardships, Tasneem remains resilient and dreams of studying dentistry abroad. Her message transcends the conflict and offers hope for a better future.
articles.title: 'Maybe it’s my last voice': Gaza teenager's audio diary captures life under bombardment

articles.description: The Beatles are set to release a 'new' record, titled "Now and Then," on November 2. The song was originally written and sung by John Lennon and has been completed with the assistance of artificial intelligence. The track, often referred to as the last Beatles song, offers a unique opportunity to hear the band working together again, long after their split in 1970. The use of AI in music remains a subject of industry-wide debate.
articles.title: The Beatles to release final track with AI help

articles.description: A British Conservative MP has been arrested on suspicion of rape and possession of controlled substances, according to police. The MP, Crispin Blunt, confirmed his arrest and stated that he is ready to cooperate with the investigation. Blunt has been suspended by his party and now sits as an independent in the House of Commons. This is the latest scandal to hit the struggling UK ruling party, which has faced several allegations of misconduct in recent years.
articles.title: British MP arrested on suspicion of rape

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Pakistan's interim government has urged illegal immigrants, including Afghan refugees, to return voluntarily or face arrest and deportation after an October 31 deadline. The move has been met with criticism from Afghan authorities and international bodies. Holding centres have been established in various locations to ensure the safe return of immigrants.  Geo-fencing has been implemented to identify areas with illegal immigrants, and a reward has been offered for information on their whereabouts after November.
articles.title: Leave or face action, Pakistan tells Afghan refugees

articles.description: France is facing an ecological challenge as bark beetles invade the forest of La Teste-de-Buch, which was previously damaged by wildfires. The beetles infest weakened pine trees, laying their eggs in the bark and causing the trees to die. Efforts to combat the infestation include tree removal, but experts warn that if nothing is done, the situation will worsen in the future. The beetle infestation has even spread to urban areas, requiring the removal of pine trees from residents' gardens.
articles.title: 'Time bomb': Tree-killing bugs threaten France's lush forests

articles.description: An Iranian court has ordered the US government to pay $420 million in compensation to victims of a failed 1980 operation to free hostages held at the US embassy in Tehran. The operation, known as Operation Eagle Claw, ended in disaster after encountering sandstorms and mechanical problems. The judiciary's Mizan Online news agency reported that during the operation, US forces had "attacked" a bus carrying Iranian passengers. This comes after previous multi-billion dollar compensation awards against Tehran by US courts.
articles.title: Iran court orders US to pay damages for 1980 hostage rescue bid

articles.description: Taliban authorities have released education activist Matiullah Wesa, who was detained for seven months. Wesa had been an advocate for girls' education in conservative rural areas of Afghanistan. His release came after condemnation from the UN and rights groups. The Taliban administration has restricted access to education for girls and women since taking control of the country in 2021. Wesa's organization, Pen Path, confirmed his release, and actress Angelina Jolie had previously called for his release in an open letter.
articles.title: Prominent Afghanistan education activist released by Taliban

articles.description: The Chief Election Commissioner of Bangladesh has expressed concerns about the upcoming polls in January, stating that a favorable environment has not been achieved yet. He warned that if there are voting irregularities, the entire election process could be suspended and new elections organized. Tensions have been escalating in the capital city of Dhaka, with simultaneous rallies announced by the ruling and opposition parties. Major Western nations, including the United States, have called for fair and credible polls in Bangladesh.
articles.title: Top Bangladesh election official warns of poll suspension in case of voting irregularities

articles.description: Hurricane Otis hit Mexico's beach resort city of Acapulco as a category 5 storm, causing at least 27 deaths and leaving the city in a state of disaster. The storm brought winds of 165 miles per hour, cutting off communications and road links with the region. President Lopez Obrador had to abandon his vehicle and walk to the scene due to blocked roads. Residents described the destruction of buildings, looting, and the struggle to find food and shelter.
articles.title: Hurricane Otis leaves at least 27 dead in Mexico's Acapulco

articles.description: Governor of Maine, Janet Mills, expressed her condolences after a tragic mass shooting in Lewiston, stating that no city or state deserves such violence. The shooting took place at a bar and bowling alley, resulting in at least 18 deaths and 13 injuries. The primary suspect, Robert Card, is still at large, prompting a massive search. Schools were canceled, and residents were advised to stay indoors. President Joe Biden ordered flags to be lowered to half-staff as a mark of respect for the victims.
articles.title: City did not deserve this terrible assault on its citizens: Governor on Maine mass shooting

articles.description: The Ukrainian Deputy Prime Minister, Oleksandr Kubrakov, has denied reports that the new Black Sea export corridor has been suspended. Ukrainian and British firms had reported that Ukraine had suspended use of the corridor due to a possible threat from Russian warplanes and sea mines. However, Kubrakov stated that all available routes established by the Ukrainian Navy are valid and being used by civilian vessels. The corridor was launched in August as a "humanitarian corridor" to bypass the de facto blockade in the Black Sea after Russia quit a U.N.-brokered deal.
articles.title: Ukraine says its Black Sea grain corridor is working

articles.description: A US-Russian journalist, Alsu Kurmasheva, has been charged by Russia for failing to register as a "foreign agent." This move by Russian authorities has been criticized by rights groups as an escalation of their campaign against independent media. Kurmasheva is the second US reporter to be detained in Russia this year. If convicted, she could face up to five years in prison. Critics argue that the law is overly broad, allowing Russian law enforcement to arrest journalists at will.
articles.title: Russia formally charges detained US-Russian journalist

articles.description: Arab countries including the United Arab Emirates, Jordan, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Qatar, Kuwait, Egypt, and Morocco have condemned Israel's targeting of civilians and violations of international law in Gaza. They argue that Israel's right to self-defense does not justify neglecting the rights of Palestinians. The ministers also criticized forced displacement and collective punishment in Gaza, emphasizing the need for a two-state solution with an independent Palestinian state. Both the West Bank and East Jerusalem, captured by Israel in 1967, should be part of this solution.
articles.title: Arab countries condemn 'flagrant violations' in targeting civilians in Gaza

articles.description: Maria Corina Machado has been declared the winner of an opposition-organized primary in Venezuela to choose a presidential candidate. The voting, which drew over 2.4 million voters, was denounced by the government as illegitimate. Despite government doubts and a ban on Machado running for office, the opposition commission declared her the winner with 93% support. Voters expressed their hopes for a change in government to address the country's complex crisis.
articles.title: Maria Corina Machado is winner of Venezuela opposition primary that government has denounced

articles.description: US News: ROUND LAKE BEACH: A man who allegedly attacked two relatives with a sledgehammer in suburban Chicago was fatally shot by police after he charged at of.
articles.title: Police in Illinois fatally shoot sledgehammer-wielding man after reported domestic assault

articles.description: Special counsel Jack Smith is seeking potential legal action against Donald Trump if he continues discussing witnesses in the federal election case. The prosecutor has requested a stricter gag order on Trump, including the possibility of imprisonment if violated. This comes after Trump hinted on social media that a potential witness might be labeled as a "weakling" and "coward" if he testified in exchange for immunity. Despite potential consequences, Trump's defiance of gag orders may continue to appeal to his voting base.
articles.title: Prosecutor Jack Smith seeks jail time for Trump's witness remarks

articles.author: Associated Press
articles.description: Halloween celebrations in South Korea were subdued on the eve of the first anniversary of the harrowing party crush that killed 159 people. Many restaurants, bars, department stores and amusement parks are avoiding Halloween-themed events as a sign of respect for the victims. Few people clad in Halloween costumes were seen Saturday in Seoul’s popular Itaewon neighbourhood, the site of last year’s deadly surge when many revellers and others packed an alley, causing people to fall on each other like dominoes. The walls of the narrow, sloped alley in Itaewon were plastered with numerous Post-it notes with condolence messages that read “We won’t forget you” and “We’ll remember you”. A mourning station established in central Seoul received many visitors, who laid white flowers and burned incense in front of photos of the victims.  In Seoul’s Hongdae area, another entertainment zone, there were only a few people wearing Halloween outfits. Authorities have deployed thousands of police, emergency and other officials since Friday for crowd control and safety of pedestrians in Itaewon and 15 other major nightlife districts in Seoul. About 200 police officers were separately mobilised to monitor narcotics use and violent crime, according to Seoul police. “I offer a deep apology again by bearing the sorrow and heavy responsibility for the disaster in my heart,” Seoul Mayor Oh Se-hoon said on Friday. “The way to overcome the pains and sorrow of the disaster is preventing this kind of incident from happening again.” Bereaved families are to hold a formal memorial service on Sunday.  In January, a police special investigation team concluded that police and municipal officials failed to work out effective crowd control steps despite correctly anticipating a huge number of people in Itaewon. Investigators also concluded that police had ignored hotline calls by pedestrians who warned of swelling crowds before the surge turned deadly. The Itaewon crush caused a nationwide outpouring of grief as the dead were mostly in their 20s…
articles.title: South Koreans hold subdued Halloween celebrations a year after party crush killed 159

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

New Zealand fought hard but could not overcome captain Sam Cane’s red card, which reduced the All Blacks to 14 men for the last 48 minutes of the match.

articles.description: Since the attack carried out on Israel by Hamas on October 7, the internet has been flooded with thousands of images of the conflict and even more rumours. articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA) has lost contact with its staff in Gaza amid the Israeli bombardment of the coastal strip. 
UNRWA Commissioner General Philippe Lazzarini said he had lost contact with the "vast majority" of his team. "This makes me immensely worried for colleagues and their families." 
He said he sincerely hoped his message would reach staff. Lazzarini described the communications blackout as "yet another action taken to try to impede the humanitarian response to the civilians of the Gaza Strip."
articles.title: UN agency 'immensely worried' after losing contact to staff in Gaza

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
After expanding its ground operations in Gaza, Israel's army said on Saturday it had identified and attacked several terror cells in the area. 
"Since early Friday evening, combined combat forces of armour, combat engineers and infantry have been operating on the ground in the northern Gaza Strip," the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) said. "As part of the operation, IDF soldiers identified terrorist cells attempting to launch anti-tank missiles and mortar shells and struck them. IDF soldiers also identified and destroyed a booby-trapped structure," it said.
articles.title: Israel Defense Forces continue expanding ground attacks in Gaza

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
A collision involving a passenger bus and several cars on a highway in Egypt killed 32 people on Saturday, the country's Health Ministry said. 
Sixty-three others were injured in the accident that happened on the Cairo-Alexandria desert road, the ministry added in an online statement. 
Earlier Saturday, state-run newspaper al-Ahram reported that investigations revealed an oil leak from a passing car led to a collision among a large number of vehicles with several of them catching fire.
articles.title: At least 32 dead in major traffic accident in Egypt

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description: Bangladesh’s main opposition party has called a nationwide strike for Sunday, after its planned mass rally to demand the ouster of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina was aborted after violent clashes in Dhaka. One policeman died and dozens more were wounded in the clashes in the capital. Mirza Fakhrul Islam Alamgir, secretary general of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), announced the day-long strike on Saturday to press home the party’s demand that Hasina resign, to pave the way for the next general election to be credibly held, under a non-partisan caretaker administration. Bangladesh is due ...
articles.title: Bangladesh opposition calls strike for Sunday after violent clashes

Asem Abu Rakaba "directed the terrorists who infiltrated Israel on paragliders and was responsible for the drone attacks on IDF [Israel Defense Forces] posts," the military wrote on Telegram. The army posted a video showing the explosion of a building from the air. The brutal attacks on October 7 in areas of Israel near the Gaza Strip killed more than 1,400 people, the majority civilians. Milita...
articles.title: Israel claims killing of Hamas air expert amid wider Gaza offensive

articles.author: Matthew Chapman
articles.description:
Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders (R-AR) has spent weeks dogged by questions from reporters and even lawmakers in her own party about the suspicious use of state funds to purchase a $19,000 lectern that no one seems able to locate — and when asked about it at a news conference about a new missile factory in the state, she lost it at the press.
Her conduct was roundly mocked by Austin Bailey in an editorial for the Arkansas Times Friday.
"A new $33 million facility will create 30 new jobs to crank out missiles for Israel’s Iron Dome and a similar U.S. system, the SkyHunter® missile. The first batch won’t roll off conveyor belts until 2025, but that didn’t stop Sanders and the defense contractors from throwing a huzzah to Israel and yawping Arkansas’s hawkish swagger," wrote Bailey. "'We don’t shy…
articles.title: Sarah Sanders mocked for 'I-know-you-are-but-what-am-I' meltdown at press

articles.author: The Charlotte Observer
articles.description:
Several years ago, dozens of elephants mysteriously dropped dead in Zimbabwe, a landlocked country in southern Africa. 
Now, researchers finally know why. 
Over several months of 2020, 35 African elephant carcasses were discovered in the Kavango–Zambezi conservation area, which encompasses five countries and is home to Africa’s largest population of elephants. 
Intriguingly, the carcasses showed no signs of outward trauma or distress; their skin was bite-free, and their tusks were intact, which ruled out predators and poachers as the cause of death.
articles.title: Dozens of elephants mysteriously dropped dead in Zimbabwe. Now, researchers know why.

articles.description: The U.N. General Assembly on Friday overwhelmingly voted to approve a measure calling for an immediate “humanitarian truce” in Gaza and demanding “continuous, sufficient and unhindered” provisions to aid civilians trapped in the heavily bombarded Palestinian enclave. The resolution — which passed by a vote of 120-14, with 45 member-states abstaining— is nonbinding but carries political weight. The United States and Israel were among the 14 nations that voted against the resolution, which calls for a “durable and sustained truce leading to a cessation of hostilities.” It also condemns “all acts...
articles.title: UN General Assembly overwhelmingly votes for immediate and sustained ‘humanitarian truce’ in Gaza

articles.author: Matthew Chapman
articles.description:
Former President Donald Trump filed a new motion in the federal 2020 election interference case, hinting that he plans to adopt a new defense.
Specifically, he wants to introduce supposed classified reports of foreign interference that support the merits of his efforts to overturn the election.
"The Indictment in this case adopts classified assessments by the Intelligence Community and others that minimized, and at times ignored, efforts by foreign actors to influence and interfere with the 2020 election," said the filing. "President Trump will offer classified information at trial relating to foreign influence activities that impacted the 2016 and 2020 elections, as well as efforts by his administration to combat those activities. President Trump will also present classified information relating to the biased and politicized nature of the intelligence assessments that he and others rejected during the events in question. Collectively, this evidence will undercut central theories of the prosecution and establish that President Trump acted at all times in good faith and on the belief that he was doing what he had been elected to do."
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
"Mostly appears to be IC assessments of foreign interference," said legal analyst Bradley Moss in response to the new filing, in a post on X. "This should be interesting."
It is unclear why Trump would put this evidence forward, as commentators have noted that Trump trying to actually prove his long-discredited claims of voter fraud and election rigging would not be relevant to the crimes of which he is accused. He is more broadly expected to mount an advice of counsel defense, although special counsel Jack Smith has long been laying the groundwork to destroy such a legal strategy.
Ironically, the other federal case against Trump that Smith is pursuing pertains to his alleged illegal theft and retention of classified information in unsecured boxes at his Mar-a-Lago country club in South Florida.
articles.title: Donald Trump files 'interesting' classified docs motion in D.C. elections case

articles.author: David Badash, The New Civil Rights Movement
articles.description:
U.S. Senator Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) is responding to a plan Democrats are putting together that would allow the Senate to vote on the more than 300 U.S. Military confirmations he has been blocking for most of the year by blaming the wars in Ukraine and Israel on Democrats and President Joe Biden.
“Democrats are preparing to send a resolution to the Rules Committee that would allow most of the 300-plus promotions Tuberville is blocking to be considered on the floor en bloc,” Punchbowl News reported Thursday. “This would dramatically reduce the number of votes the Senate would need to take to approve the long-stalled promotions. It would be in effect for a little over a year,” and not be a permanent change.
“The resolution, described to us by several sources, includes a carve-out for upper-…
articles.title: Sen. Tuberville concocts falsehood about who's responsible for wars in Ukraine and Israel

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
Blake Masters has dropped out of the U.S. Senate race, announcing Thursday that he is running for Congress instead. It paves the way for failed gubernatorial candidate Kari Lake to take the Republican nomination. 
Masters, who failed in his attempt at a U.S. Senate seat in 2022 against Sen. Mark Kelly (D-AZ), announced his new campaign on social media, saying that he's seeking the eighth congressional district. 
"Biden has failed. We need Trump back. We need to stop inflation, Build the Wall, avoid WW3, and secure Arizona's water future," the candidate said. "We need to fight for our families."
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
The district, which includes part of Peoria and north Glendale, is currently held by Rep. Debbie Lesko (R), who assumed office in May, 2018. Lesko announced that she was retiring earlier in 2023 and there are now 13 candidates running for the seat. 
Masters was supported and funded for his Senate run by billionaire investor Peter Thiel, who pledged $5 million on the race but ultimately spent $15 million.
articles.title: Blake Masters abandons Arizona Senate race — and lets Kari Lake have GOP nomination

articles.author: David Edwards
articles.description:
Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) offered a resolution on Thursday to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (R-MI) for what she said was an "insurrection." 
Greene brought the resolution to the House floor after Tlaib participated in a peaceful protest at the Capitol to call for a ceasefire in Gaza.
"A resolution censuring Representative Rashida Tlaib for anti-Semitic activity, sympathizing with terrorist organizations, and leading an insurrection at the United States Capitol Complex," Greene said, reading her resolution. "Whereas by leading an anti-American and anti-Semitic insurrection on October 18, 2023, Rashida Tlaib followed Hezbollah's orders to carry out a day of unprecedented anger, following an explosion at a Gazan hospital, lying about Israel's responsibility for the attack, which United States intelligence agencies said was not perpetrated by Israel."
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to hold office again?
"And whereas members of Congress who denounce the United States while praising terrorist organizations are unfit to hold office," she continued. "Now, therefore, be it resolved that Representative Rashida Tlaib be censured."
The chair ruled that the full House would consider Greene's resolution at a later date.
Watch the video below.
articles.title: 'Unfit to hold office': Marjorie Taylor Greene tries to censure Dem for 'insurrection'

articles.description:
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says US President Joe Biden welcomed the fact that he is going to meet China’s leader, Xi Jinping. 

Mr Albanese’s remarks come after the Prime Minister wrapped up a state visit to the United States, strengthening ties and pushing for key AUKUS legislation to be passed this year. 

A major theme of the visit was policy in the Indo-Pacific, particularly towards China, and US President Joe Biden had some pointed criticism for the People’s Republic ahead of the Prime Minister’s visit to China in November.  

“Australia and China have different political systems, of course, and different values,” Mr Albanese told Sky News Political Editor Andrew Clennell. 

“One of the reasons why the relationship with the United States is so close is because we do have that common commitment to human rights, to democracy, and to our values. 

“It’s important that Australia stabilise the relationship – that’s something that the US is seeking as well.”
articles.title: Joe Biden welcomed Anthony Albanese’s expected visit to China to meet Xi Jinping

articles.description:
An IDF spokesperson has claimed Israeli troops plan to “dismantle totally” all of Hamas’ military infrastructure in Gaza. 

Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Conricus told Sky News Australia the country was involved in a war it “did not start”. 

“It started by Hamas crossing into our communities and butchering more than one thousand of our civilians," he said.  

“In response to that we are going to dismantle, totally, all of the military infrastructure in Gaza which facilitated this attack and we are going to dismantle Hamas from ever being capable of doing it again.” 

The Lieutenant’s comments follow a targeted ground raid by Israel’s military in northern Gaza on Thursday. 

A wider offensive is expected.
articles.title: Israeli troops aiming to ‘dismantle’ Hamas’ military capability

The repercussions will be severe either way. The group has used the threat of its weapons as a deterrence against Israel, but Hizballah leadership also knows that

articles.author: Amos Fox
articles.description:
With Israel’s looming ground offensive against Hamas, and considering the population density of Gaza, urban warfare will certainly be a significant component of the conflict. Urban warfare in Gaza will not be a deft war of maneuver, but rather a slow, methodical grind of attrition. The Israel Defense Forces’ relatively small size in relation to the population density and urban sprawl of Gaza will strip away many of the Israeli military’s inherent asymmetries. Moreover, two additional factors will increase the voracity of urban warfare. First, due to Gaza’s small size, there is almost no land available to fight a war
The post Urban Warfare, Sieges, and Israel’s Looming Invasion of Gaza appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: Urban Warfare, Sieges, and Israel’s Looming Invasion of Gaza

articles.author: Leo Blanken
articles.description:
Welcome to Rewind & Reconnoiter. Each week, we’ll ask one of our authors to look back at an article they’ve written for War on the Rocks in light of a current news event. Did their argument hold up? Read more below to find out. *** In 2018, Leo Blanken, Kai Thaxton, and Michael Alexander wrote “Shock of the Mundane: The Dangerous Diffusion of Basic Infantry Tactics” for War on the Rocks, in which they argued that “the marginal improvement of tactical prowess in violent non-state groups may lead to outcomes that have strategic implications for global U.S. counter-terrorist and counter-insurgent operations.”

articles.description:
AI imagines what would happen if Biden declares and activates the Selective Service Act and begins drafting 20 years old to war pic.twitter.com/896Htrtteu
— The Post Millennial (@TPostMillennial) February 27, 2023
  
Military Times/AP: No, the US military isn’t ‘laying the groundwork’ for a draft

 
Claim: The U.S. military is planning to reinstitute the draft.

 
AP’s Assessment: False. Defense officials confirm the armed forces have made no such recommendation to Congress or the president, which are the entities empowered to authorize a draft.

 
The Facts: With America’s allies in Europe and the Middle East embroiled in conflicts with no end in sight, social media posts are claiming the U.S. military is considering mandating regular citizens to enlist in the armed forces. 
A number of those are sharing a headline from a Sept. 25 article from the Mises Institute, a libertarian group in Alabama that reads: “The US Military Is Laying the Groundwork to Reinstitute the Draft.”

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: "U.S. military draft"  has been trending on search engines for the past few weeks. Videos like the one above and rumors on social media are probably fueling it .... Video of Biden calling for a military draft is AI-generated, not real | Fact check (USA Today). More here .... Fighting 'Joe Biden's wars': False rumor of 'draft' spreads across social media as 'medicated' Gen Z slammed for not signing up (Meaww), and here .... Fact Check: Video of Joe Biden calling for a military draft was created with AI (Reuters).
Just one more note. 
On the eve of Russia's invasion of Ukraine the Kyiv government was telling everyone to not worry, and to stay home. Within 24 hours of Russia's invasion, the Ukraine government immediately closed its border to men of military age who can be drafted. The U.S. government will do the same. Telling everyone that everything is fine, until the very moment that the "shit hits the fan".
articles.title: Is The US Military ‘Laying The Groundwork’ To Reinstitute the Draft? The Pentagon Says No

articles.description:
Warzone: B-21 Raider Has Begun Taxi Tests 
The Air Force is hopeful that the B-21 Raider stealth bomber will take to the skies for the first time before the end of the year. 
The U.S. Air Force's first pre-production B-21 Raider stealth bomber is now undergoing taxi testing, moving around the sprawling Plant 42 in Palmdale under its own power. This is the latest developmental milestone for the aircraft as it continues to move closer to its first flight, which could come before the end of the year. 
"I can confirm the B-21 is conducting ground taxi activities. Rigorous testing is a critical step in the B-21 flight test program," an Air Force spokesperson confirmed to The War Zone today. "Extensive testing evaluates systems, components, and functionalities. This testing allows us to mitigate risks, optimize design, and enhance operational effectiveness." 
Read more .... 
 
WNU Editor: The first contracts for production of the B-21 are being drawn up .... Northrop expects B-21 low-rate production contract by year-end (Flight Global). 
 New Image Reveals B-21 Raider Taxiing Ahead Of Its First Scheduled Flight 
New Image of B-21 Bomber Tail Shows Different Exhausts and Rear Deck from B-2 -- Air And Space Forces Magazine 
B-21 Raider begins taxi tests, a key step before first flight -- Defense News 
B-21 starts taxi tests; Northrop expects first flight by year's end -- Defense One 
New Image Reveals B-21 Raider Taxiing Ahead Of Maiden Flight -- Zero Hedge 
B-21 Raider: US Stealth Bomber Commences Taxi Testing Ahead Of Its First Scheduled Flight -- EurAsian Times
articles.title: New Image Reveals B-21 Raider Taxiing Ahead Of Its First Scheduled Flight

articles.description:
Wikipedia 

Reuters: US halts exports of most civilian firearms for 90 days 
WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. has stopped issuing export licenses for most civilian firearms and ammunition for 90 days for all non-governmental users, the Commerce Department said on Friday, citing national security and foreign policy interests. 
The Commerce Department did not provide further details for the pause, which also includes shotguns and optical sights, but said an urgent review will assess the "risk of firearms being diverted to entities or activities that promote regional instability, violate human rights, or fuel criminal activities."

 
Read more ....

 
WNU editor: This is unprecedented. The only exceptions to this export ban are Israel and Ukraine. 
So why the ban and this hoarding of weapons and ammo? 
My gut tells me that with US military stockpiles now at an all time low and supply chain disruptions are  growing. In this environment the US has made the decision that with international relations deteriorating and threats of a major war growing everyday, the US needs to replenish some of their stockpiles ASAP.
articles.title: US Halts Most Civilian Firearm And Ammunition Exports For 90 Days

articles.description:
Time: Biden Cast Doubt on Gaza’s Death Toll. Palestinian Officials Responded With 6,747 Names 
In the past three weeks, more than 1,400 people in Israel and 7,000 Palestinians have been killed amid fighting between Israel and Hamas. That is, if you believe the casualty figures coming out of the region. This week, U.S. President Joe Biden suggested that the Palestinian death toll in Gaza, which has been under heavy bombardment by Israel following Hamas’ Oct. 7 massacre, is not to be trusted. 
“I’m sure innocents have been killed, and it’s a price of waging a war,” Biden said at a press conference on Wednesday. “But I have no confidence in the number that the Palestinians are using.” The President didn’t offer further evidence for his skepticism of the Palestinian health ministry's data, which the U.S. State Department has cited both internally and publicly, in the latter case as recently as March. (When asked to provide evidence to support Biden's statement, the White House referred TIME to comments made by U.S. National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby, who on Thursday reiterated the President’s assertion that the death toll cannot be taken “at face value” because the “Gaza Ministry of Health is just a front for Hamas.”) 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: This is the current death toll .... Ministry: At least 7,000, including 2,913 children, killed in Israeli strikes on Gaza (AFP). 
More News On The Accuracy Of Casualty Numbers From Gaza

 
What is Gaza’s Ministry of Health and how does it calculate the war’s death toll? (AP)
 
Despite Biden's doubts, humanitarian agencies consider Gaza toll reliable (Reuters)
 
Gaza health ministry publishes list of war dead as credibility attacked -- UPI
articles.title: Are Gaza's Casualty Numbers Accurate?

Zero Hedge: Tucker Carlson Blasts Zelensky's Orwellian War On Orthodox Christianity & West's Deafening Silence 
A proposed new Ukrainian law which will ban the Ukrainian Orthodox Church for merely maintaining communion and ties to the Russian Orthodox Church based in Moscow is poised to go into effect. This after its churches and monasteries have already in some instances been subject to brutal raids by police or else ultra-nationalist thugs, which has been met with international silence despite the egregious violation of religions freedom. Bishops have been hauled before courts, priests have been thrown in jail, monks and nuns have been thrown onto the street.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: Ukraine is not the only government banning Orthodox Christianity. I live in Canada, and my archbishop has been sanctioned .... Canada Imposes Sanctions On The Head Of The Russian Orthodox Church (July 10, 2022).

J. Scott Applewhite. © AP Photo 

Bloomberg: House Will Consider Ukraine, Israel Aid Separately, Johnson Says 
(Bloomberg) -- The House of Representatives will consider new military assistance for Ukraine and Israel as separate measures, the newly installed speaker said Thursday, complicating President Joe Biden’s attempts to secure support for both US allies. 
“Our consensus among House Republicans is that we need to bifurcate those issues,” Speaker Mike Johnson told Sean Hannity of Fox News. He said he delivered that message to White House officials after meeting with Biden earlier in the day. 

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: As it should be. 
US Congress Will Consider Ukraine, Israel Aid Separately

GOP Senators Present Draft Splitting US Aid to Israel From Funds to Ukraine - Reports -- Sputnik
articles.title: US Congress Will Consider Ukraine, Israel Aid Separately

articles.description:
Ukrainian servicemen prepare to fire at Russian positions from a U.S.-supplied M777 howitzer in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on July 14, 2022. VOA has learned the U.S. will provide up to $150 million in additional military aid for Ukraine as soon as Oct. 25, 2023. 

VOA: Exclusive: $150 Million in Ukraine Military Aid Expected Wednesday 
PENTAGON — The United States is providing up to $150 million in additional military aid for Ukraine in a package expected as soon as Wednesday, three U.S. military officials tell VOA, a week after Ukraine used its newest weapon from the United States to pummel Russian military targets deep into Russian-controlled eastern Ukraine. 
The package includes more GMLRS rockets for High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems (HIMARS), munitions for the National Advanced Surface-to-Air Missile System (NASAMS), TOW anti-tank missiles, AIM-9 Sidewinder missiles and 155 mm rounds, according to two of the officials who spoke to VOA on condition of anonymity to discuss the package prior to its announcement.

 
Read more ....

 
Update #1: US to supply Ukraine with new $150 million military aid package (Ukrainska Pravda) 
Update #2: US Announces New $150Mln Military Package for Ukraine, Including NASAMS, AIM-9M, Stinger Missiles (Sputnik)

 
WNU Editor: I am not surprised that the U.S. is sending more military aid to Ukraine. I am surprised that it is only $150 million.
articles.title: U.S. Sending More Military Aid To Ukraine

Reuters: 900 US troops heading to Middle East to bolster defenses as attacks surge 
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - About 900 more U.S. troops have arrived in the Middle East or are heading there to bolster air defenses for U.S. personnel amid a surge in attacks by Iran-affiliated groups, the Pentagon said on Thursday.
As tensions soar over the Israel-Hamas war, U.S. and coalition troops have been attacked at least 12 times in Iraq and four times in Syria in the last week, Pentagon spokesperson Brigadier General Patrick Ryder told reporters. 
A total of 21 U.S. forces have suffered minor injuries, the vast majority of them traumatic brain injuries.

 
Read more ....

 
WNU Editor: One source that I trust is saying that two more US aircraft carrier strike groups are going to be deployed to the Middle East in the coming days. This will make a total of 4 US aircraft carrier strike groups being deployed to the Middle East. 

If true, this is not a deployment to deter other actors to get involved in the Israel - Hamas war, this is a deployment to strike a major target.
articles.title: More US Troops Heading To Middle East

articles.description:
The Tonnerre ship can carry helicopters, armored vehicles, tanks and troops | Laura Kayali/POLITICO

 

Politico: The EU prepares for war — and this French ship is the tip of the spear 
France’s powerful amphibious helicopter carrier is a floating village with gyms and a boulangerie … plus missiles, machine guns, landing craft, choppers and tanks. 
ABOARD THE FRENCH HELICOPTER CARRIER TONNERRE — John Denver’s "Country Roads," a folk song from 1971, resounds through the Tonnerre. 
It’s 7:30 a.m., and some of the crew aboard the Mistral-class amphibious helicopter carrier are already eating breakfast — loading up on coffee, bread and jam ahead of a planned exercise to storm a Spanish beach. It's been a short night, and plans for the landing have changed several times. 
The French assault vessel — 199 meters long, 32 meters wide and able to carry 21,500 metric tons — is a key element in the European Union’s first live military exercise in October off the southern coast of Spain.  
Read more .... 
 France Deploys One LHD And Two Frigates To The Eastern Mediterranean 
France Deploys One LHD, Two Frigates to the Eastern Mediterranean -- Naval News
 
France sends Mistral-class amphibious assault ship Tonnerre to help Gaza -- Navy Recognition
